height: 240px;\"><div class=\"flex-caption\"><h1>Cerebrum Anthology 2016</h1><p>Cerebrum&nbsp;is back in book form by popular demand. The Anthology brings together more than a dozen articles and book reviews from the 2016 monthly Web edition, offering&nbsp;inquisitive readers the chance to read about new and provocative ideas in neuroscience from a cross-section of prominent neuroscientists. Available now at <a href=\"http://amzn.to/2naKbtL\">Amazon</a> and <a href=\"https://cdcshoppingcart.uchicago.edu/Cart/Cart.aspx?BK=Y&amp;ISBN=9781932594607\">Chicago Distribution Center</a>.</p><a href=\"http://www.dana.org/Publications/cerebrum2016/\" class=\"buttons_slider\">Find out more</a></div></li><li style=\"width: 100%; float: left; margin-right: -100%;\"><img src=\"/uploadedImages/Home/Slider/SAYBrain-grab-5.jpg\" alt=\"SAYBrainvideo-framegrabforslider\" title=\"SAYBrainvideo-framegrabforslider\" align=\"right\"><div class=\"flex-caption\"><h1>Successful Aging and Your Brain</h1><p>It’s never too late to start living a brain-healthy life! Scientists\ndescribed how they are connecting the dots between symptoms and brain mechanisms\nduring the BNA 2017 Festival of Neuroscience.&nbsp;</description></p><h3><a href=\"News/Garrett/How-Dishonesty-Can-Snowball\">How Dishonesty Can Snowball</a></h3>by Neil Garrett, Ph.D.<h4></h4><p><description></description></p><table align=\"left\" cellspacing=\"3\"><tbody><tr><td><img src=\"/uploadedImages/Images/Thumbnails-80px/neil-garrett-80(1).jpg\" alt=\"Neil-Garrett-t\" title=\"Neil-Garrett-t\"></td></tr></tbody></table><p>Once people start lying, they are often more willing to lie for higher and higher stakes. Some of their willingness is due to external factors, but a new line of research is teasing out internal factors, as well.</p><p>&nbsp;</p><p></p><h3><a href=\"http://www.dana.org/news/Preventing_PTSD_A_Possible_New_Use_for_Ketamine\">Preventing PTSD: A New Use for Ketamine?</a></h3>by Kayt Sukel<h4></h4><p><description>The drug has shown promise in treating depression and extinguishing fearful memories. Could it also prevent the descent from fearful memory to full-blown disorder?</description></p><h3><a href=\"News/The_Deprived_Brain/\">The Deprived Brain</a></h3>by Carl Sherman<h4></h4><p><description>Children who lag cognitively after spending time in orphanages can make up the difference by young adulthood, suggest two longitudinal studies, but some behavior and emotional issues remain—or even increase. This suggests that environmental influences might lead to disorders with or without genetic precursors.</description></p><h3><a href=\"http://www.dana.org/Briefing_Papers/When_is_the_Brain_Mature/\">When is the Brain “Mature”?</a></h3>by Kayt Sukel<h4></h4><p><description>Though most people in the US consider 18 to be the age maturity is reached, developmental neuroscientists say there isn’t a one size fits all age, nor a one size fits all method to measure it. In our new briefing paper, we explore how new scientific findings regarding the brain, adolescence, and neurodevelopment are informing law and policy across the country.</description></p><h3><a href=\"http://www.dana.org/Brain_in_the_News/An_Open_Letter_to_Congress/\">An Open Letter to Congress</a></h3>by Guy McKhann, M.D.<h4></h4><p><description><br></description></p><table align=\"left\"
